__data__.text: Barcelona, the capital of Catalonia, is situated in the Spanish Levant on the Mediterranean coast, specifically between 41° 16'-41° 30' N latitude and 1° 54'-2° 18' E longitude. Covering 102.16 km2, the city is located on a narrow 11 km by 6 km coastal plain, flanked by the Serra de Collserola on one side and the deltas of the Besòs and Llobregat rivers on the other. Montjuïc mountain, standing at 184.8 m, separates the city from the Llobregat delta. Barcelona serves as the capital for the comarca of Barcelonès, the province of Barcelona, and is the primary urban hub in Catalonia for population, politics, economy, and culture.

In the context of Barcelona's significance, the text highlights its role as a vital political, cultural, and infrastructural center. It is the seat of the Catalonian autonomous government, Parliament, provincial council, and archbishopric, as well as the IV Military Region. Barcelona boasts a port, airport, and extensive rail and road networks. As of 2015, it was the second most populous city in Spain and the eleventh in the European Union, with approximately 1,604,555 inhabitants. The text also mentions the city's administrative divisions.

As of 2015, Barcelona was the second most populous city in Spain and the eleventh in the European Union, with around 1,604,555 inhabitants. It serves as a significant political, cultural, and infrastructural hub, housing various government entities and a well-developed transportation system. Barcelona is divided into 10 districts and 73 neighborhoods, including the historic Ciutat Vella, the expanded Eixample, and the largest district, Sants-Montjuïc. These divisions reflect the city's growth from its Roman and medieval origins to its modern-day expansion.

Barcelona's district Les Corts, one of the city's ten districts, was incorporated in 1897 and had its origins in a medieval farmhouse, as suggested by its name derived from the Latin word "cohors." Initially an agricultural area, Les Corts underwent significant urban growth in the mid-19th century, resulting in the development of the Corts Noves area. The district's name can be found in various streets, plazas, and intersections within its boundaries. Additionally, the district includes the park, promenade, and road named Montjuïc, which originates from the Catalan word for "Jewish mountain."

The district of Les Corts, established in 1897, was once a rural area originating from a medieval farmhouse, as indicated by its name derived from the Latin word "cohors." It contains various locations bearing its name, and it encompasses the Pedralbes area, which was previously part of Sarrià and features a square and avenue named after the Santa María de Pedralbes monastery, derived from the Latin "petras albas" (white stones). Sarrià-Sant Gervasi is another district, resulting from the merger of Sarrià and Sant Gervasi de Cassoles, and is one of the largest districts due to its inclusion of a significant portion of Serra de Collserola. The name Sarrià stems from the Latin Serrianum, appearing in several streets and squares such as Sarrià Major, Sarrià Menor, Camí Vell de Sarrià, and the road from Sarrià to Vallvidrera.

The district of Les Corts, founded in 1897, was originally a rural area associated with a medieval farmhouse, as suggested by its name derived from the Latin word "cohors." Sarrià-Sant Gervasi, one of the largest districts, is a result of the merger of Sarrià and Sant Gervasi de Cassoles, which includes a portion of Serra de Collserola. The name Sarrià comes from the Latin Serrianum, while Sant Gervasi de Cassoles, previously an independent municipality, is located on the street of Sant Gervasi de Cassolas and Passeig de San Gervasi. It encompasses the old municipality of Vallvidrera, which was incorporated into Sarrià in 1892 and features locations named after it. Gràcia, another district, originated from the old village of Gràcia, incorporated into the city in 1897, and was initially an agricultural area that developed an urban and industrial network in the early 19th century, with its origin in the church of Nostra Senyora de Gràcia i Sant Josep, established in the 17th century.

The district of Gràcia emerged from the old village of Gràcia, which was an agricultural area with the church of Nostra Senyora de Gràcia i Sant Josep established in the 17th century. The name Gràcia has persisted in various streets and plazas. Horta-Guinardó, another district, is formed from the old town of Horta, incorporated in 1904, and the Guinardó district. It includes locations named after both areas. Nou Barris, the most recently created district, was formed on land segregated from San Andrés de Palomar and is named after the original "nine neighborhoods" within it, although there are currently 13.

Nou Barris, the most recent district, was established in 1982, formed from land separated from San Andrés de Palomar. Its name originates from the initial "nine neighborhoods" within it, now totaling 13. The district's oldest area is Vilapicina, a historic village built around the Santa Eulalia de Vilapicina sanctuary in the 10th century. San Andrés (6.56 km2, 145,983 inhabitants) was once an independent municipality, known for agriculture and milling until the mid-19th century when industries started to move in.

San Andrés, now a part of Nou Barris, was previously an agricultural and milling region until numerous industries started to set up in the mid-19th century. Its past is commemorated through the San Andrés stream, the main street of San Andrés, and the street of Palomar. San Martin, incorporated in 1897, is named after the old village of San Martin de Provensals and is divided into four neighborhoods: Sagrera, Muntanya, Clot, and Taulat, all of which are memorialized through dedicated streets. Barcelona's administrative division has changed over time, with the initial delimitation in 1389 dividing the city into four quarters based on significant religious institutions.

The administrative divisions of Barcelona have evolved over time. Initially, it was divided into four quarters in 1389, centered around significant religious institutions, with a grid established in the 15th century that included El Raval ("arrabal"). A reform in 1769 created five districts, each with eight neighborhoods, based on different areas of the city such as the port, industrial, and residential areas. In the 19th century, numerous divisions were made for political reasons, including those in 1837 and 1878, which established four and ten districts, respectively. San Andrés and San Martin are now part of Nou Barris, with their past commemorated through dedicated streets and the San Andrés stream.

Barcelona's administrative divisions have changed over time. Initially, it was divided into four quarters in 1389 and then into a grid in the 15th century. A reform in 1769 created five districts based on different areas of the city. In the 19th century, political reasons led to numerous divisions, including those in 1837 and 1878, creating ten districts. The end of the 19th century to the early 20th century saw the incorporation of bordering municipalities and a reorganization into ten districts. In 1933, another reform resulted in ten districts, including Barceloneta, Poble Sec and Montjuïc, Sarriá, and others. Throughout these changes, some districts were merged, and new ones were created, often commemorating historical areas or neighborhoods.

In 1933, Barcelona was reorganized into ten districts, one of which was San Martín de Provensals, combined with Clot and Poblenou. Later, in 1949, two more districts were added, making a total of twelve. However, the current division into ten districts was approved in 1984, aiming for decentralization and functional delimitation while respecting the historical and morphological identity of each district, ensuring comprehensive welfare coverage for the residents.

In 1984, Barcelona's districts were reorganized to decentralize and delimit functionally, while respecting the historical and morphological identity of each district, ensuring comprehensive welfare coverage. This resulted in the current division into ten districts, which were formed by considering the historical boundaries of the old city, its expansion, and the merged municipalities. However, some areas were assigned to different districts than their historical origins, such as Pedralbes (formerly Sarriá) becoming part of Les Corts, Vallcarca (formerly Horta) incorporated into Gracia, El Guinardó (originally from San Martín) added to Horta, and the creation of Nou Barris from San Andrés. The name Barcelona is believed to originate from an Iberian settlement called Barkeno, which evolved into the Latin Barcino during the Roman colony foundation in the 1st century B.C.

The name Barcelona originated from an Iberian settlement called Barkeno, which transformed into Barcino during the establishment of the Roman colony in the 1st century B.C. Although there are legends suggesting a Carthaginian origin linked to Amilcar Barca, it appears to be unlikely. The first written record of Barcino is found in the 1st century A.D. by Pomponius Mela, and Claudius Ptolemy mentioned it as Βαρκινών (Barkinṓn) in the 2nd century A.D. The toponym underwent changes between the 4th and 7th centuries, with variants like Barcilo, Barcilona, Barcinona, Barcinonem, Barchinon, and Barchinonam appearing in various sources.

The name Barcelona evolved from the Roman colony of Barcino, established in the 1st century B.C., with earlier forms like Barcino, Barcinona, and Barchinon. The city, originally called Colonia Iulia Augusta Faventia Paterna Barcino, was founded by Roman colonizers on Mount Táber and initially took the form of a castrum. It reached its peak during the 2nd century with a population of 3,500 to 5,000 inhabitants. The forum served as the city's central square for public life and business. The names Barcellona and Barcinona appeared in the 4th and 7th centuries, respectively, with the current form Barcelona emerging for the first time in the 7th century.

During the Roman era's peak in the 2nd century, Barcelona's population ranged from 3,500 to 5,000 inhabitants, with the forum as the central hub for public life and business. The city had two main roads: the cardo maximus (Libretería and Call streets) and decumanus maximus (Obispo, Ciudad, and Regomir streets). The Roman influence remains in street names like Via Julia, Via Augusta, Via Favencia, and Via Barcino, derived from the city's full Latin name. The Middle Ages marked the following era.

During the Middle Ages, following the Roman Empire's collapse and preceding the formation of the Catalan counties, Barcelona experienced various conquests by civilizations such as the Visigoths and Arabs, as well as a phase within the Carolingian Empire. Barcelona eventually established itself as a county and an integral part of the Crown of Aragon, becoming the principal political and economic center of the Principality of Catalonia and a significant maritime and commercial hub in the Mediterranean Sea. The city's population grew to around 25,000 inhabitants, expanding from its original urban nucleus (the Gothic Quarter) to include the El Raval district. The medieval street layout was irregular, with narrow, short streets named after geographical features, such as Arenas, Cantos, Arcos, Arcos de Junqueras, Balsas de Sant Pere, or Rec.

After the fall of the Roman Empire and before the formation of the Catalan counties, Barcelona underwent conquests by the Visigoths and Arabs and was part of the Carolingian Empire. The city became a significant county in the Crown of Aragon, serving as the primary political, economic, maritime, and commercial hub in the Mediterranean. The population grew to around 25,000 inhabitants, expanding from the Gothic Quarter to include El Raval. The medieval street layout featured narrow, short streets named after geographical features, wells, anthroponyms, and religious figures. Examples of well-named streets include Pou de la Cadena, Pou de la Figuera, Pou de l'Estany, and Pou Dolç. Later, streets were named after anthroponyms, such as Amargós, Avinyó, Bellafila, and Montcada, as well as religious figures like San Antonio Abad, San Pablo, and San Olegario.

After the growth of Barcelona as a major county in the Crown of Aragon, the city's streets started to be named based on various categories, such as religious figures, geographical features, and wells. Some examples of religiously named streets include San Antonio Abad, San Pablo, San Olegario, as well as others like Santa Madrona, San Agustín, Santa Mónica, and so on. Additionally, streets were also named after trades and guilds, which had their own designated zones in the city. Examples of these include San Pedro (Alta, Baja and Mediana), Montsió, and many more.

In addition to streets named for religious figures and geographical features, many Barcelona streets were also named based on trades and guilds, which often clustered in specific zones. Examples of these include streets for shearers, hole makers, silversmiths, shellers, coopers, brocade makers, cambistas, carders, corders, cotton makers, cutlers, potters, esparteria, sword makers, manteros, frenería, merchants, mirror makers, cutters, tapineria, muleteers, and glass makers. Some streets were also named after notable buildings or establishments such as palaces, cathedrals, hospitals, and baths.

Barcelona's streets were named for various trades and guilds, forming specific zones. One such street, Carassa Street, is believed to have been named after a carota advertising a nearby brothel. Historically, the Jewish quarter, the Call, existed from 692 until its destruction in 1391. It was situated between Fernando, Baños Nuevos, Palla, and Obispo streets and enclosed by a wall. The Call had two synagogues, baths, schools, and hospitals, and its legacy endures through Call and Arco de San Ramón del Call streets. Eventually, settlements emerged outside the city walls.

The Jewish quarter, the Call, is remembered through the streets named after it and Arco de San Ramón del Call. As the population grew, new settlements formed outside the city walls, developing around churches and monasteries such as Santa María del Mar, San Cucufate del Riego, San Pedro de las Puellas, Santa María del Pino, Santa Ana, and Portal del Bisbe. The Raval neighborhood, initially a rural area with religious buildings, also emerged. With this expansion, a new wall was constructed in 1260, extending from San Pedro de las Puelles to the Atarazanas, facing the sea.

The expansion of the city in the 13th century led to the construction of a new wall with eight gates, some of which lent their names to present-day streets and locations, such as Portal del Angel, Puertaferrisa, and La Boqueria. Ancha Street, once the widest in the city, was built to connect Santa Maria del Mar with Framenors and was home to wealthy families. In the same century, urban reforms took place near Bisbal Gate, creating a new square called Plaza Nueva, and a beach area was transformed into the Pla de Palau square, where the Viceroy's palace was later situated.

During the 13th to 19th centuries, Barcelona underwent significant urban development, including the construction of a new wall with gates that now lend their names to present-day streets. Ancha Street was built to connect important landmarks and was home to affluent families. Urban reforms led to the creation of new squares, such as Plaza Nueva and Pla de Palau, which became the city's center in the 18th and 19th centuries until it was replaced by Plaça de Catalunya. Additionally, an extensive road network emerged, connecting the city to nearby suburbs, mills, quarries, churches, and fountains. The city could also grant the privilege of "carrearage" to other localities, bringing them under its institutional protection. The Plaça del Rei, built in the 14th century, was originally a corral and market, and its name comes from its proximity to the Palau Reial Major.

During the 13th to 19th centuries, Barcelona experienced significant urban development, including the construction of a new wall and gates, the emergence of an extensive road network, and the creation of new squares that served as the city's center. Barcelona shared jurisdiction over 74 localities, which were considered as streets, with the monarch. These localities, such as Igualada, Cardedeu, Vilamajor, and others, were under the ownership of the city and the usufruct of the monarch. This period also marked Barcelona's inclusion in the Hispanic Monarchy, which was formed by the union of the crowns of Castile and Aragon in the early modern age.

During the early modern age, Barcelona became part of the Hispanic Monarchy, following the merger of the crowns of Castile and Aragon. This era was marked by fluctuations between prosperity and economic crises, including plague outbreaks in the 16th century and conflicts such as the Reapers' War and the War of Succession. However, the economy recovered in the 18th century due to trade with America and the onset of the textile industry. Despite the growing population, which reached approximately 100,000 inhabitants, urban development was limited, with the exception of the construction of the sea wall and bastions in the first half of the 16th century. Barcelona's status as a non-capital city resulted in fewer large-scale projects during this time.

During the early modern age, Barcelona underwent urban development in the form of the construction of the sea wall and bastions, such as Levante, Torre Nueva, San Ramón, and Mediodía, in the first half of the 16th century. The port was also renovated, and the area between the Pla de Palau and La Rambla was embanked, resulting in the creation of the Paseo del Mar, now known as Paseo de Colón. In addition, the region around the cathedral saw changes, including the establishment of the Plaza de Cristo Rey and Plaza de San Ivo. In the 17th century, the city wall was further expanded with the addition of five new gates: San Severo, Talleres, San Antonio, San Pablo, and Santa Madrona. Overall, urban development was limited during this time due to Barcelona's status as a non-capital city.

During the early modern age, Barcelona experienced urban development with the construction of sea walls and bastions, as well as the renovation of the port. The city's growth continued in the 17th century with the addition of five new gates to the city wall. In the 18th century, two new roads were built across the plain of Barcelona, and the La Barceloneta neighborhood was constructed on reclaimed land, showcasing academic Baroque urban planning with a grid of orthogonal streets and elongated house blocks. The neighborhood's name is commemorated in various locations, while other streets are named for maritime themes and historical figures related to the sea. Urban development was somewhat restricted due to Barcelona not being a capital city.

During the late 18th century (1776-1778), la Rambla, an ancient watercourse that marked the western border of Barcelona since the Middle Ages, underwent urbanization. Originally inhabited by theaters and convents, the inner city wall was removed, buildings were realigned, and a new landscaped promenade, similar to French boulevards, was created. La Rambla, also known as Las Ramblas, has different section names, reflecting its history, such as Rambla de Canaletas, Estudios, San José, Capuchinos, and Santa Mónica, which are derived from water pipes, an old university, a Carmelite convent, a Capuchin convent, and a church, respectively. This development was limited since Barcelona was not a capital city.

During the late 18th century, la Rambla, an ancient watercourse, was urbanized and transformed into a French boulevard-like promenade, which was divided into sections bearing names with historical significance, such as Rambla de Canaletas, Estudios, San José, Capuchinos, and Santa Mónica. This term stems from the Arabic word "ramla" (رملة), meaning "sandbank" or intermittent watercourse. Similar promenades, like those of San Juan and Gracia, were also planned around the same period, although they were constructed later. Simultaneously, Count del Asalto Street, now Nueva de la Rambla Street, was laid out, named after Francisco González de Bassecourt, the Captain General of Catalonia who initiated its creation. Additionally, the term "rambla" has been generically applied to numerous thoroughfares in the city, such as Badal, Brasil, Cazador, Carmelo, Cataluña, Fabra i Puig, Guipúzcoa, Mar, Once de Septiembre, Pueblo Nuevo, Prat, Prim, Raval, and Volart. The development of these promenades was limited since Barcelona was not a capital city at that time.

In the late 18th century, la Rambla was converted into a French-style promenade, dividing it into historically named sections and inspiring similar developments like Paseo Nuevo (or Paseo de la Explanada) and others. This era also saw the first instance of dedicating a street to a specific character, initiated by Francisco González de Bassecourt. The Edicto de obreria ordinance in 1771 regulated private works, focusing on street alignment, paving, sewage, and house numbering. The 19th century brought significant economic revitalization, due to the Industrial Revolution and textile industry, which led to a cultural renaissance in Barcelona.

During the 19th century, Barcelona experienced significant economic revitalization due to the Industrial Revolution, particularly in the textile industry, which spurred a cultural renaissance. The city underwent expansion after the demolition of its walls between 1854 and 1859, leading to the Eixample project designed by Ildefonso Cerdá in 1859. The Citadel was also torn down in 1868, and its land was converted into a public park. The population surged to 400,000 inhabitants by the end of the century, mainly due to immigration from other parts of Spain. This century was marked by continuous political shifts and power struggles between liberals and conservatives, which occasionally manifested in the renaming of a few sites, such as Pla de Palau to Plaza de la Constitución, Plaza de San Jaime to Plaza de la Soberanía Nacional, and Plaza de San Agustín to Plaza de la Igualdad during the Liberal Triennium (1820-1823).

The 19th century saw Barcelona's growth and modernization, driven by the Industrial Revolution and an influx of immigrants. The city expanded with the Eixample project and the conversion of the Citadel's land into a public park. Political instability led to frequent name changes for key sites, reflecting power shifts between liberals and conservatives. For instance, Pla de Palau became Plaza de la Constitución, Plaza de San Jaime was renamed Plaza de la Soberanía Nacional, and Plaza de San Agustín was named Plaza de la Igualdad during the Liberal Triennium (1820-1823). Later, Plaza de la Igualdad remained unchanged until the Franco dictatorship.

Streets were renamed to honor Spanish monarchs and political figures, such as Ferdinand VII street, initially called Ferdinand (Ferran in Catalan), which was dedicated to the Spanish king and later alternated its name with that of Duque de la Victoria (General Espartero) depending on the ruling political faction. The Inquisition street was renamed to Count of Barcelona after the Inquisition ended in 1835.

The abolition of the Inquisition in 1835 resulted in the renaming of the street that previously bore its name to Count of Barcelona. Furthermore, the urban planning of the city was positively impacted by the extensive land confiscation of 1836, which resulted in the construction of new public spaces, such as La Boquería and Santa Catalina markets, the Gran Teatro del Liceo, and two squares designed by Francisco Daniel Molina: Plaza Real and Plaza del Duque de Medinaceli. The new health regulations at the time led to the disappearance of several parish cemeteries, and in their place, new public squares were established, including Santa María, del Pino, San José Oriol, and San Felipe Neri, which were named after the respective churches.

The end of the Inquisition in 1835 and the confiscation of land in 1836 led to the creation of new public spaces, such as La Boquería and Santa Catalina markets, the Gran Teatro del Liceo, and squares like Plaza Real and Plaza del Duque de Medinaceli. The renaming of Plaza de San Jaime to Plaza de la Constitución in 1840, and later to Plaza de la República in 1931 and back to Plaza de San Jaime in 1940, was due to changes in government. Additionally, the liberal government of 1840 initiated the placement of marble plaques with cast lead letters to label streets. In this period, new squares were established near churches, such as Santa María del Pino, San José Oriol, San Felipe Neri, San Justo, San Pedro, and the former church of San Jaime.

The bombardment by General Espartero in the same time period resulted in citizens erasing street names and numbers to avoid identification and payment of fines, leading to the need for a more permanent labeling system. This coincided with the creation of new public spaces and squares near churches during this period of government changes.

In the mid-1800s, due to the bombardment by General Espartero and the subsequent creation of new public spaces, the street naming system was regulated, resembling the current one. A local jeweler, Josep Rossell i Imbert, named nearby streets after jewelry during Gracia's urbanization around 1850. The Diputation of Barcelona developed new road layouts, including Sarriá Avenue, the Sants to Les Corts road, and the Sagrera to Horta road, which is now Garcilaso Street. During the Progressive Biennium of 1854-1856, Reina Cristina and Obispo streets were renamed General Dulce and General Zurbano, aligning with liberal values. The Plaza de la Unión was also established, symbolizing the Liberal Union party.

During Gracia's urbanization and the expansion of Barcelona in the mid-1800s, street naming was regulated, with some streets named after jewelry and new road layouts developed. The Plaza de la Unión was created to symbolize the Liberal Union party, and although some street names were later changed to Castilian, not all changes were accepted by the public, who continued to use traditional names. The city's expansion was facilitated by the demolition of medieval walls in 1854.

The removal of medieval walls in 1854 allowed Barcelona to expand onto the neighboring plain. In 1859, the City Council established a committee to organize a competition for urban expansion projects, which was initially awarded to Antoni Rovira i Trias. However, the Ministry of Development intervened and implemented Ildefonso Cerdá's project instead. Cerdá's plan, presented in 1859, featured a grid-like layout with 20-meter-wide streets running northwest-southeast, intersected by others headed southwest-northeast and parallel to the coast and Collserola mountain range.

In 1859, the City Council organized a competition for urban expansion projects, and Ildefonso Cerdá's plan was ultimately chosen. Cerdá's design consisted of a grid-like pattern with wide streets intersecting at right angles and forming square blocks, primarily 113.3 meters on each side. He intended to build only two sides of each block, leaving the remaining spaces for gardens, but this was not realized as most of the buildable land was used for construction. The buildings were designed with an octagonal floor plan, and main avenues, such as Diagonal, Meridiana, Paralelo, Gran Vía de las Cortes Catalanas, Paseo de San Juan, and several large squares, were planned. Additionally, Cerdá's project included the opening of three major avenues in the old part of the city, connecting the Eixample with the coast and Montjuïc.

In the urban expansion plan selected for Barcelona in 1859, Ildefonso Cerdá proposed new ring roads around the old city, replacing the demolished walls. These roads were named San Pablo, San Antonio, Universidad, and San Pedro. The original grid-like street system was initially identified by numbers and letters, but was later changed to a nominal one by the City Council's 4th Development Section. The task of naming the streets was assigned to writer Víctor Balaguer, who chose Catalanist names inspired by Catalonia's history, as a way to honor its past and promote Catalan towns.

In the 1859 urban expansion plan for Barcelona, Ildefonso Cerdá proposed new ring roads and a change from a numerical to a nominal street-naming system. The task of naming the streets was given to Víctor Balaguer, who chose Catalanist names to honor Catalonia's history and promote its towns. He selected names related to the Crown of Aragon, institutions, historical figures, battles, events, and industries, with some modifications over time, such as the renaming of the University street to Enrique Granados in 1916.

In the 1859 urban expansion plan for Barcelona, Víctor Balaguer made modifications to Ildefonso Cerdá's proposal, including renaming the University street to Enrique Granados in 1916 and proposing names like Atenas, Desclot, Barceló, Capmany, La Coronela, and Llobregat, which were not ultimately realized. To balance this, the municipal corporation and technical body suggested names honoring Spain's history, such as Floridablanca, Sepúlveda, Enna (now Ramon Turró Street), Marqués de Campo Sagrado, Pelayo, Vergara, and Trafalgar. The new street names were approved in December 1863, along with provisions dividing the Eixample territory between Barcelona and neighboring municipalities, establishing house numbering, and regulating street labeling with plaques or provisional tablets on the first building of each block.

In the 1859 urban expansion plan for Barcelona, Víctor Balaguer proposed new street names, while the municipal corporation and technical body suggested names honoring Spain's history. The numbering of houses was established and street labeling was regulated, with a plaque or provisional tablet identifying the street on the first building of each block. Balaguer's proposed names were not fully realized, but some streets were named after him, including those honoring battles, historical figures, and economic concepts. The Eixample section in Sant Martí de Provençals was named by the local consistory, with some names repeating and others surviving, such as Prim, Llacuna, Bogatell, Provensals, Pueblo Nuevo, and Taulat.

The 1859 urban expansion plan for Barcelona involved naming streets after various economic concepts, historical figures, cities and provinces in Spain, international cities, and countries. Specifically, streets were suggested to be named after figures such as Peter IV, Philip II, Bac de Roda, Padilla, Sancho de Ávila, John de Austria, Andrade, San Antonio María Claret, Lope de Vega, Espronceda, Mistral, Wellington, Cristóbal de Moura and Buenaventura Muñoz, as well as cities and provinces like Álava, Ávila, Badajoz, Bilbao, Cantabria, Cartagena, Castilla, Ciudad de Granada, Guipúzcoa, La Coruña, Murcia, Palencia, Pamplona, Vizcaya and Zamora, and international cities like Paris, London, Rome, and Buenos Aires, along with countries like Morocco, Bolivia, Paraguay, Peru, and Venezuela. However, not all proposed names were implemented. The Cerdá Plan did not include Plaza de Cataluña, which was originally intended to be a block of buildings, but has since emerged as a significant square in the city.

The Cerdá Plan for Barcelona's urban expansion in 1859 proposed naming streets after historical figures, Spanish cities, international cities, and countries, but didn't include the area where Passeig de Gràcia is currently located, which was intended to be a block of buildings. However, the location became a popular gathering spot with commercial and recreational activity, leading to the unofficial naming of the square. The name became so widely used that the city council officially adopted it by 1865, and it was included in Victor Balaguer's compendium of Barcelona's streets. The Glorious Revolution of 1868 brought further changes to the city's street names.

The Glorious Revolution of 1868 led to significant alterations in Barcelona's street names, with the city council modifying many streets in a session on January 26, 1869. Some of the changes included Cristina becoming Prim, Fernando VII changing to Libertad, Isabel II becoming Alcolea, Princesa renamed to Cádiz, Rambla de Isabel II to Rambla de Cataluña, Pla de Palau to Plaza del Comercio, Plaza Real to Plaza Nacional, and Plaza del Rey to Plaza del Pueblo. These changes persisted throughout the First Republic (1873-1874), with the exception of Cristina Street, which was ultimately named Prim instead of República, and the addition of renaming Portal de la Paz to Portal de la Junta Revolucionaria in 1873.

The Glorious Revolution of 1868 resulted in numerous street name modifications in Barcelona and its surrounding towns, including Gracia, Sants, San Martín de Provensals, and Sarriá. These changes persisted throughout the First Republic (1873-1874), with a few exceptions. In Barcelona, Cristina Street became Prim, and in 1873, Portal de la Paz was renamed Portal de la Junta Revolucionaria. In Gracia, Isabel II Street was divided into Luna and Mariana Pineda Streets, and Plaza Isabel II became Revolution Square. Several streets, such as Príncipe, Princesa, Virrey, Virreina, and Caballeros, were renamed Escuder, Argüelles, Maldonado, Torrijos, and Zurbano, respectively. In Sants, Isabel II became Riego, Plaza de la Iglesia turned into Plaza de la Federación, and a portion of the Bordeta road was named Calle de la Constitución. San Martín de Provensals saw Isabel II square transformed into Prim square, and Princesa street turned into Topete street. Lastly, Sarriá's Isabel II became Libertad, Príncipe changed to Serrano, and Cristina was renamed Prim.

The First Republic (1873-1874) brought about several street name modifications in Barcelona and surrounding towns, driven by the intention to remove religious connotations. Examples include Cristina Street becoming Prim, Portal de la Paz transforming into Portal de la Junta Revolucionaria, and Isabel II Street divided into Luna and Mariana Pineda Streets. Sants saw Isabel II become Riego and Plaza de la Iglesia turn into Plaza de la Federación. Despite the short duration of the Republic, attempts were made to change street names to more appropriate ones. The First Republic's street name modifications in Barcelona and surrounding towns mostly reverted after the Bourbon restoration, except for a few like Rambla de Cataluña and Béjar street in Hostafrancs. Later, the Montjuïc cemetery opened in 1883, featuring religious street names, and the 1888 Barcelona Universal Exposition significantly influenced the city's economy, society, urban development, arts, and culture. In the 20th century, Barcelona experienced significant social changes, most notably a massive increase in immigration, causing the population to grow from 530,000 inhabitants in 1900 to 1,500,000 by the end of the century. During the 20th century, Barcelona expanded by annexing several neighboring towns, causing the city to grow from 15.5 km2 to 77.8 km2 and the population to increase from 383,908 to 559,589. In the early 20th century, Barcelona underwent expansion by annexing nearby towns, resulting in duplicate street names, such as multiple streets named after St. Joseph and St. John. In the early 1900s, Barcelona, having annexed nearby towns, faced street name duplication issues. A 1907 report tackled this by renaming 361 streets, using various criteria. In the early 1900s, Barcelona, following its expansion, dealt with street name duplications by renaming many streets, often using notable figures and landowners' names. During Barcelona's expansion in the early 1900s, many streets were renamed to honor landowners, their relatives, or historical figures, which was a common practice among town councils. During Barcelona's growth in the early 1900s, many streets were renamed to honor various individuals, including local landowners, relatives, and historical figures. During Barcelona's expansion in the early 1900s, several streets were renamed to honor notable individuals and mark significant events. The creation of Via Layetana, proposed in the Baixeras Plan of 1878, took place between 1908 and 1913, with funding from the City Council and Banco Hispano Colonial. In the 1910s and 1920s, Barcelona underwent significant changes in street names, often to commemorate notable figures and events. During the Primo de Rivera dictatorship (1923-1930), Spanish became the dominant language in street signs, and many street names were changed to honor the Spanish royal family, military figures, and Spanish historical events. For instance, Avinguda de la Nacionalidad Catalana became Argüelles and then Alfonso XIII, Riera de Cassoles turned into Avinguda del Príncipe de Asturias, and Avinguda de América was changed to Reina María Cristina. During the Primo de Rivera dictatorship, there was a significant renaming of streets to promote Spanish culture and diminish Catalan influences. Additionally, several streets were dedicated to military men, including Calle de la Concordia becoming Almirante Aixada, Calle Número 2 del ensanche de San Andrés becoming Almirante Próxida, and Diagonal de San Pablo being dedicated to General Primo de Rivera. During the Primo de Rivera dictatorship, numerous streets were renamed to highlight Spanish culture and reduce Catalan influences. In the early 1930s, following the end of Primo de Rivera's dictatorship and the start of the Second Republic, the streets in Gràcia underwent significant changes. After the Republic began, the streets were changed from Castilian to Catalan, although this was not immediately reflected on the plaques due to the slow and costly nature of the process. The new council, led by Jaume Aiguadé, adopted Esteve's proposals and added around a hundred more changes, which they approved in August 1931. Under Jaume Aiguadé's leadership, the new city council adopted and expanded upon Martí Esteve's previous proposals, reversing many changes made during the dictatorship, particularly those related to the military, royalty, and nobility. The Barcelona Street Nomenclature Committee designs street signs with visibility in mind, using contrasting colors and lettering of an appropriate size. The signs are typically made of marble with raised letters in a dark color. In 1842, the labeling of streets began with marble plaques and lead letters due to a bombardment and subsequent fine. There are around 34,350 street signs in Barcelona, and they come in various forms, such as road signs on traffic lights and vertical signs on masts. The committee avoids naming streets after individuals based solely on land donations and seeks family approval for such dedications, with the exception of certain instances involving saints, popes, kings, or royal figures.

In the past, Barcelona's street signs were made using marble plaques and cast lead letters, similar to today's versions, but with sinuous contours resembling picture frames. They were initially placed in Ciutat Vella and the Eixample district. In the early 20th century, tile letters on sidewalks were introduced, displaying street names, but their installation stopped in the 1960s. From the 1940s to 1960s, tin plates with bluish backgrounds and silver letters were used, which were later replaced with marble signs. Some historical examples, such as those in Londres and París streets, can still be found today.

In the mid-twentieth century, Barcelona switched from tin to marble signs, which are still used today. Building numbers in the city typically follow a pattern of even numbers on one side and odd on the other, with squares being a notable exception. The numbering system in the Eixample district, in particular, starts on the sea side for streets running in the sea-mountain direction and on the Llobregat side for those running in the Llobregat-Besós direction. Notably, Gran Vía de les Corts Catalanes has the highest numbering at 1198, while Anisadeta Street is the shortest, spanning only 2 meters.
